heisig_chinese_memo: What a handsome soldier. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He's like a modern samurai!
heisig_story: The shape of this kanji, slightly differing from that for soil by virtue of its shorter final stroke, hints at a broad-shouldered, slender-waisted warrior standing at attention. When feudalism collapsed, these warriors became Japan's gentlemen.

humanum_full_description_en:
"Poetry. Xiaoya. "Caifu" Zheng Xuan wrote: "Sergeant, sergeant." " Science " is based on an axe, probably because a soldier is a person who often has to carry an axe to do things, so the axe is turned to differentiate the word " shi ". The axe is a symbol of kingship, so it can also mean " king ." In the oracle bone inscriptions, " shi " and " king " have the same form, which can be pronounced as " shi " or " king " (Lin Yuan). See " king ". Later, " shi " was used as a general term for men, and it also referred to scholars, clerks, officials, and officials. "Said Wen": "Shi, things are also. Counting starts with one, and ends at ten. From one to ten. Confucius said: Put ten into one as a scholar. All the geniuses of all scholars follow the scholar.

The curved blade of a horizontal axe at the bottom of the inscription " shi " was later simplified into a horizontal pen with the same length as the horizontal drawing above; after the small seal, the two horizontal lines were determined to be the upper long and the lower short, distinguishing it from " earth. " .

Bronze is used as a general term for men, Lu'erzhong: "and my father and brother's concubine", and teacher: "Fu (captive) scholar, female, sheep, cow". Wang Sun Gaozhong: "and my father and brother, and the scholars." It also means the sergeant, the new Qihu symbol: "Fanxingshi wears armor and employs more than fifty soldiers. He must know the king symbol and dare to do it." It is also used as an official name.

The average person hears the Tao, as if he has heard it, but also as if he has not heard it. The inferior people laughed and didn't believe it. "Guodian Jane. "Lao Zi Jia" Jane 8: "An ancient benevolent person must not be (micro) drowning (subtle) profound knowledge, deep and unwilling (knowledge)", which means that ancient people who are good at scholar must be subtle and profound, deep and understanding. The silk book in Han Dynasty means the warrior, "Mawangdui silk book. The 70th line of Lao Tzu's Jiaben: "A man who is good at war is not martial, and he who is good at war is not angry." The 176th line of the Old Unknown Book of Lao Zi Jia: "The scholar has the aspirations to the gentleman." It is also called " thing ", which means service, "Mawangdui Silk Book." "Poetry. Xiaoya. "Caifu" Zheng Xuan wrote: "Sergeant, sergeant." " Science" is based on an axe, probably because a soldier is a person who often has to carry an axe to do things, so the axe is turned to differentiate the word " shi". The axe is a symbol of kingship, so it can also mean " king." In the oracle bone inscriptions, " shi" and " king" have the same form, which can be pronounced as " shi" or " king" (Lin Yuan). See " king". Later, " shi" was used as a general term for men, and it also referred to scholars, clerks, officials, and officials. "Said Wen": "Shi, things are also. Counting starts with one, and ends at ten. From one to ten. Confucius said: Put ten into one as a scholar. All the geniuses of all scholars follow the scholar. The curved blade of a horizontal axe at the bottom of the inscription " shi" was later simplified into a horizontal pen with the same length as the horizontal drawing above; after the small seal, the two horizontal lines were determined to be the upper long and the lower short, distinguishing it from " earth." .
